annotation.TEXT: Overall though, if you're looking for a good Boss Rush styled game (and one with some nice creativity behind it), I'd definitely recommend this one. You don't even have to play the first game to have a good time with it either (and trust me, you'd be way better off playing this one over the first game).

The next boss is a bit of a pain, if mainly for the same reason that Nine-Ball was so annoying to deal with. As far as I can tell, the only way to hit this boss is through using Death Crimson. It may be possible to jump on its hands and fire at her face (or by getting the same results using Rush Coil and Jet), but using Death Crimson is easily the much faster method.
R. Buster Dive Bright Skull Toad R. Search Drill -> R. Cannon Pharaoh W. Star Ring Wire Dust Balloon
For those of you that want to go straight to the action though, skip ahead to around 3:10.

With the 8 main bosses taken care of, we now have one extra fight to deal with before moving on to Dr. Vinegar's castle. We also get more cutscenes along the way. Even though I still can't understand what's being said, I still enjoy the neat sprite-work here (though Mega Man's face admittedly looks a bit off - but then again, his expressions are pretty amusing, especially his "look at all the fucks I don't give" face).

The final phase takes the form of a capsule fight. Its weakness is, what else, Death Crimson. By this point, I'm starting to get a bit fed up with this weapon. I'll admit that here it makes sense to use it (since Dr. Vinegar is flying around), but Skullo Energy could have easily taken its place as well.
Cutscene time again, along with more strange facial expressions. Feel free to skip to 6:13 if you don't feel like watching Mega Man's bewildered face for a few minutes.

Well, there we have Rockman Infinity 2. Honestly, I'm not sure what to say after all of that. This game is a bit of an insane trip from beginning to end, and despite some of the issues I brought up here and there, I still loved almost every minute of this.

And with that, it's off to Dr. Vinegar's castle. From what I can gather so far (even though I can't understand the plot, aside from a poorly translated version of it via taking the synopsis from Ukege's website and sticking it into Google translate), Dr. Vinegar has apparently kidnapped Roll and taken Dr. Light hostage. I'm assuming there's probably more to this, but for right now, that's about all I can figure out.

Trust me when I say that this sequel far exceeds the first installment. It does everything right that the first game fell short on. The weapon set is great (for the most part), the bosses are way more balanced and fun to fight against, and the options/continue progress is greatly improved. Though it's difficult to judge compared to some of the more traditional Mega Man games I've played before, I'd say that at least for a Boss Rush styled game, this is among my favorites.

The third fortress boss is a Devil-type enemy, but one with a few new twists to it. Aside from having a wider frame, the sections that break off can react differently depending on what you do. This boss happens to be incredibly weak to Big-Bang Attack, but if you charge it up while its pieces are transitioning, the sections will not only move faster, but actually form into much larger chunks (resembling things like giant feet and fists), making them more difficult to avoid.

The first fortress boss is called "Joe Majinga." I have no idea what this guy is supposed to be (other than partly being a take on Sniper Joe). If I had to take guess however, I'd assume it also has something to do with the Dragon Quest series (if mostly due to the sound effects he uses).

With that being said however, there are a few gripes I have with this boss. The first being his weakness, LS99 Moonlight, doesn't have enough ammo to fully take him down (Aqua Man syndrome strikes again). The other is with his eye-laser attack, which requires you to get close to him to avoid it. If you don't manage to do this in time, the only other way around it is by abusing Rush Jet (though this method at least gives you a free hit or two on him).

As said before though, the game isn't without its faults. The Mugen engine can only do so much with a system like this, but Ukege managed to get around that quite a bit. There can be a few hiccups with the controls here and there, though it doesn't seem to happen as often as it did in the first game.

For the record (and thankfully unlike the first game), the final teleporter that appears in the boss rush stage takes you to the next stage, where you fight Dr. Vinegar separately (similar to MM3's boss rush room).

Beyond that, there's a few other minor things, such as with Death Crimson having more weakness affiliations than any other weapon in the game. The boss rush in the fourth fortress stage is also rather unnecessary, but at least you can skip it completely in the options menu.

The second phase isn't any more difficult, but reflected projectiles no longer damage it. It also has a new firing pattern as well. While this could easily make for a somewhat active and intense fight, I find it to be somewhat ruined by its weakness -which happens to be Death Crimson. Honestly, I would have preferred it to be Meat Shot (at least that way, you'd actually have a reason to jump on the platform/move around more).

Dr. Vinegar's Metal Slug inspired machine is actually a bit easier compared to the one from the first game. For one, it only has two phases instead of three. The first phase's weak point is in its turret, which you can heavily damage by reflecting its projectiles back with the Tsuppari Strike.

Time for the true final boss. Of all the references in this game so far, this one is easily my favorite (aside from Dio and Skullomania). All of Apocalypse-Vinegar's moves are lifted directly from the original in MSH Vs SF, which actually seem to translate quite well into a Mega Man game.

Marisa acts roughly the same as the Robo-Len Archive from the first game, except here, she has a single lifebar. She also copies various characters from Touhou rather than other Mega Man bosses (from what I understand, she can also copy bosses from the first Rockman Infinity, but you have to let the fight drag on a really long time for it to happen).
